description:
Onam is a time when one of Kerala‚Äôs most prominent indigenous art forms, Pulikali, is performed. In some places, it is also known as Kaduvakali. The rhythmic dance is enacted by artistes who are dressed as a puli (cheetah) or a kaduva (tiger). While Pulikali is an art form performed on the outskirts of Thiruvananthapuram and Kollam, the dance in Thrissur, which has an ancestry of about 200 years, is considered the oldest. It is also the most popular and classical of all types of Pulikali. Special training is mandatory to perform this art form.

title: Coconut Palm - Kerala's Tree of Life | State Tree of Kerala | Kerala Tourism
description:
Coconut palm (Cocos nucifera), the state tree of Kerala, is a very familiar tree in the coastal belts across the world, especially the tropical eastern regions. Kerala and its people owe a lot to this tree, starting to its very name! Kerala means the 'Land of Coconuts', with Kera meaning coconut tree in local parlance. Coconut also plays a huge role in Kerala's economy as it is one of the main sources of income for many in the state. After 717 long years, the village of Kalliot in Kasaragod bore witness to a magnificent sight - of over 100 Theyyams (Theyyam ‚Äì a ritual dance form of worship) performing in abandon at the Kalliot Devi Temple. This one-of-a-kind temple festival 'Perumkaliyattam Mahotsavam' was held in this shrine after a gap of 717 years in 2019. A unique ritual, Perumkaliyattam is usually held once in every 12 years at temples in Malabar. This magical blend of art, rituals, tradition, music, and heritage, sees fiery performances by Theyyams. Experience the celebration of the divine in all its glory in this video.
